newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai stocks drop to new low on foreign selling.
newsitem.headline: Thai stocks drop to new low on foreign selling.

text.p: Thai stocks slid for the sixth straight trading day to close at a new 6-1/3 year low as foreigners continued to sell shares following the central bank's revision of lower economic growth, brokers said.
The composite SET index ended down 13.25 points or 2.19 percent to 592.18 on Monday. Turnover was modest with 3.46 billion baht changing hands.
"The central bank's projection of lower economic growth of six percent sparked selling today," said one broker at United Securities.
"The market expects the economic growth to be lower (than six percent) as exports remain sluggish," the broker added.
The closing level on the SET was the lowest since January 1991. Losers led gainers 231 to 73 with 85 issues ending unchanged.
Bank of Thailand governor Rerngchai Marakanond was quoted as saying the country's gross domestic product (GDP) should grow about six percent in 1997.
The central bank earlier projected the GDP growth to be at 6.8 percent this year.
Thai Farmers Bank eased five baht to 104 on the most active trade of 290 million baht.
Thailand's largest bank, Bangkok Bank lost four to 159 and Krung Thai Bank ws down one to 25.75.
Electricity Generating gained 0.50 to 57. The company on Monday announced a net profit of 460 million baht in the first quarter compared with 286 million in the same period a year ago.
TelecomAsia dropped 3.50 to 31.50, Shinawatra Computer and Communication fell two to 132.
